message: Your child needs 10 to 11 hours of sleep each night in order to pay attention in school, fight off sickness & stay healthy
Brush your child?s teeth regularly in the morning and before bed in order to prevent cavities in the teeth & reduce plaque build-up
Spend adequate time with your child. Do not let your job prevent you from spending time with your baby
Feed your child the food you serve the rest of your family. Give him 3-4 meals a day, with snacks too
Spend adequate time with your baby. If you are with him for long enough, you will be able to detect symptoms of ill-health quickly
Your baby is 3 years old now. His weight should not be below 11kg. For optimal growth, a healthy balanced diet is needed
Do not keep electric wires, coins or other small objects within the reach of your child. Little kids have a tendency to put everything in their mouths
Turn hand washing into a regular routine at home. Get your child to wash his hands with water & soap upon coming home & before eating
Always ask at your health facility the latest information about vaccines for your baby
Does your child have a sore throat? Feed him soft food. You could also try offering his favourite foods. This will encourage him to eat
Ensure your baby eats plenty of fruits & vegetables. Also include meat, fish, beans, and nuts for well-rounded nutrition at breakfast, lunch & dinner
Eliminate snacks as much as possible! Fast food & soft drinks are a growing concern due to the increased rate of obesity in children
Be an excellent parent! Ensure your child visits the dentist for check-ups once a year.  This is for an overall examination of the teeth & gums
Keep things like drugs, alcohol, household cleaning supplies, kitchen knives, or anything dangerous out of the reach of your baby
You can delay pregnancy by using family planning methods. There are many methods available. Discuss your options with a doctor
If you smoke, you should consider quitting-for both your health and most importantly that of your child
Take your child to the doctor for regular checkups at least twice a year so you can pick up any potential health problem on time
Communicate regularly with your child?s kindergarten school teacher to know how he is doing in school
After illness, give your child one extra meal a day for the next two weeks. Continue until he regains any lost weight
Take your child to the clinic regularly to check if he is growing well. A doctor will answer any questions you may have on feeding
Measure your child's upper arm every month with a piece of string. If his arm grows, then he is growing well. If not, give him more food
Boil water before drinking it. Keep boiled water in clean containers and keep them covered. Scoop the water with clean cups
Make sure your child is using proper safety equipment such as seatbelt, helmet, etc., at all times
Use a separate plate for your child's food. After use, wash it straightaway with hot, soapy water. This will prevent infections
Your child's stools have germs which can make him ill. Dispose of stools in a toilet. Always wash your hands afterwards
Set some money aside for emergency trips to the hospital. Start saving now so you won?t have to worry about paying for transport later
Toilets and stools are home to germs. Always keep toilets clean. This will prevent germs from breeding
Fever, shivering or fast breathing are signs of illness. If he is too weak, it is an emergency so go to the hospital immediately!
As a 3 year old, your baby?s weight should not be below 11kg. For optimal growth, a healthy balanced diet is needed
Green vegetables, beans and egg yolks are good sources of iron. Serve with fruits like orange and pineapple. They help to absorb the iron
Set up a washing stand with soap and water near to where you prepare food and near the toilet. This will help you regularly wash your hands
It?s common for children to catch worms from the ground. Clinics offer regular deworming treatments. Get your child dewormed at the clinic
Keep your child away from anyone who coughs and sneezes. Many illnesses are spread through coughs and sneezes, including pneumonia
Small children's tastes change often. What he may hate now, he may love in a month! So it's worth trying hated foods again
Take your child to the clinic for treatment when he shows signs of illness. A cough and breathing difficulty means that he is ill
Keep current with all vaccinations to ensure protection from serious diseases
Give your child clean and safe drinks. Boil water to make it clean. Boil animal milks before giving them to your child
This week, tell your child a bedtime story. You can make it up as you tell it! Your child will still enjoy it
Try to offer new foods to your child often. Try mixing foods he likes with new ones
On a hot day, give your child plenty of clean water to prevent dehydration. Boil the water and then cool it before giving it to your child
Salt Sugar Solution can help if your child has diarrhea. Add 10 level teaspoons of sugar & 2 level teaspoons of salt to water from 2 pure water sachets
Measure your child's upper arm with a tape. Note the size, and measure again in a month. If he hasn't grown, give him more food
Children have great imaginations. Anything can become a toy! Just make sure it's clean, not small enough to choke on and has no sharp edges
Wash fruit and vegetables to remove dirt and germs. Wash them well before feeding them to your child
Do you know a household tape and weighing scale is all you need to have a healthy child? Monitor his growth today for strong and healthy living
Make sure all food you feed your child is fresh. If it smells or looks different, it may have spoiled. Spoiled food can cause sickness
You can prevent infections by washing your child's hands before she eats. Dirty hands in the mouth can cause diarrhea
If your child has diarrhoea, Salt Sugar Solution can save the day! Add 10 level teaspoons of sugar and 2 level teaspoons of salt to 1L of water
If your child complains of pain while passing stools and if his stools are dry, hard and small, he may be constipated. Give him plenty of water
A measuring tape and weighing scale is all you sometimes all you need to have a healthy child. Monitor his growth today for strong and healthy living
If your child is constipated, feed him lots of clean water, fresh fruit and beans. They help to soften his stools
If your child?s constipation does not improve after a few days, take him to the clinic for treatment. Don?t give him any other medicine
Keep your children in a room away from the kitchen area when you are cooking. Cooking makes smoke, and breathing in smoke is harmful
Make time for your child during meal times. Quality time with the family helps your child enjoy mealtimes and be confident in the future.
Open the windows while cooking to let the smoke out of the house. Smoke in the house can harm your child?s lungs and make him ill
Ask your family members to help with chores so you have more time with your baby. Your baby learns from you and your family
Wash your child's dirty clothes with soap and water and dry them well. Clean clothes will help protect him from infection
Loose, watery stools are a sign of diarrhoea.  If your child has diarrhoea for more than one day, go to the clinic for ORS, medicine and Zinc
Your child has plenty of energy. Chase him outside. Grab him and hug him when you catch him. Watch him laugh!
Never leave your child alone near water. Small children can drown easily. If you do leave, make sure a responsible adult is watching him.
Cover wells that your child could access. He could fall in and get injured or drown. Cover wells with anything that your child can't move.
Is your child attached to a particular toy or object? This is normal. It helps your child to feel safe and secure.
Undernutrition can affect your child?s survival, growth and development. Please ensure to monitor growth of one of the leaders of tomorrow
Your child is undergoing a period of rapid growth. Proteins & vitamins are needed; milk, fruits, vegetables & meat are good sources
Turn old food containers or boxes into toys. Your child can stack them on top of each other. Make sure they're clean, with no sharp edges
You can tell your child is healthy if his weight steadily increases. If his weight is the same or reducing, seek advice at the clinic
Does your child shout? Show him how to hold his finger to his lips and say ?shhh?. Play at whispering in his ear and let him whisper to you
Keep stored drinking water covered. This will protect it from animals, dust and dirty hands. Keep scoops and dippers clean too
Keep your food and utensils covered. This will protect them from rats, mice, cockroaches, flies and dust
Does your child have a blocked nose? It could make it hard for him to eat. Help him to gently blow his nose
Keep your stoves clean all the time. After cooking, remove all remnants of food on the stove. This will minimize smoke when cooking.
Cook in areas away from the rest of the family so they do not breathe in too much smoke. Breathing smoke can make your child ill
Your child should recognize when he needs to urinate now. This is a big step towards growing up!
Block access to areas of water, like wells and ponds. You could build a fence around your home. This will protect your child from drowning
If your child was submerged in water, and was unconscious, take him to the hospital as fast as you can! In the meantime, keep him warm
Never store your cooking fuel in drinks bottles like Coca-Cola bottles. Your child may drink from it by mistake
If you use firewood to cook, dry it before you use it. This will minimize the amount of smoke that is made by cooking
Soak your beans overnight before cooking them. This will make reduce cooking time and reduce the amount of smoke created by cooking
Always hold your child's hand when crossing roads. This will stop your child from running across busy roads, and being run over
Always watch over children playing outdoors near roads. Encourage your neighbours to do the same. This will prevent accidents
Encourage older siblings to play or feed your child. This will encourage them to protect and care for each other when they are older
Is your child coughing a lot, and vomiting afterwards? Take him to the hospital. He may need medical treatment
Does your child have HIV? Make sure he takes ART medicine every day. Ask your doctor if he needs other medicines as well
Teach your child how to wash his hands. Help him wet them and lather soap. Make sure he does this after using the toilet and before eating
Check how safe your home is. Block access to balconies, or areas that your child could fall from. Make your home safe for your active child
Make a safe play area for your child. Remove any furniture with sharp corners, or anything he may be tempted to climb
If your child has a bladder infection, he can get medicines at the clinic. Make sure he takes all his doses for the infection to clear
Don't feed your child fizzy drinks, ice cream, tea, coffee, sweets and candies. They have no goodness in them and harm your child's growth
Fever and frequent or infrequent urination are signs of an infection. If you see any of these signs in your child take him to the hospital
Sleep under an insecticide-treated net to keep mosquitoes away. Malaria is passed by mosquitoes at night
Food that remains on plates can cause sickness. Wash plates, cups and cutlery well. If food sticks on plates, soak them in boiling water
Worms are picked up from the ground and make your child ill. Thick socks or shoes will help protect your child when he plays outside
Does your child sleep on a raised bed? Place cushions on the floor next to the bed. This way, he won't be injured if he rolls out of bed
Never leave your child alone in places where he could fall and get hurt. This includes balconies, window ledges and stairways
Is there a risk your baby might have HIV? Take your child for an HIV test. Knowing early will help you give your child the best care possible
Congratulations! Your child is 4 years! Think of how much your child has accomplished. This is all because of you. Well done!
SMS message
Your child is now 4 years old! You?ve looked after him so well. This is worth celebrating!
Give your child lots of praise when he attempts something new. Your praise will encourage him to keep trying. He wants to impress you!
If you and your partner have disagreements, try not to let your child know. It could upset him
Children are very curious and can play with anything. Remove sharp objects, detergents or medicine from the floor or where your child plays
Protect your child from dehydration. Give him lots of clean water and dress him in loose cotton clothes
Your child may nap less often now. He is growing up! He's still growing fast though, so let him sleep whenever he needs to.
If your child hits his head, and is bleeding, dizzy or disorientated, take him to the clinic. He may need medical treatment
Praise your child's good behaviour, instead of punishing bad behaviour. This is a better way to teach your child rules and discipline
If your child gets a cut, wash it well to prevent infection. Then rub some antiseptic on the cut. You can get antiseptic at the pharmacy
Talk to other mothers and share your experiences with them. Other mothers are a great source of information for tips on raising your child
As a mother, you will know when something is wrong with your child. Trust your intuition and go to the clinic for help
Make sure your baby visits the dentist for check-ups once a year for an overall examination of the teeth & gums as well as thorough teeth cleaning
Your child is too precious to take risks with. If he is ill, go to the clinic for good care. Don't wait. Children can get ill very quickly
Always get your child's medicines from the hospital. If your family suggests other types of medicine, explain to them that the hospital is safest.
Your child is getting taller as his bones grow. Give him foods that make strong bones like milk, cheese, yoghurt and leafy green vegetables
A child with diarrhoea needs food. Feed him extra food and water. If it lasts longer than a day, go to the clinic for ORS and zinc tablets
Many children eat slowly. If your child doesn?t finish his meal in 30 minutes, don?t make him. Put the food somewhere cool. Try again later
Most insecticide-treated nets can have up to 21 washes before you need another one. Keep count of the number of times you wash them
If it?s stuffy inside a mosquito net, open the windows. The windows will let air in and the net will protect you from the mosquitoes
Your child looks less like a baby now. He's upright, active, taller and slimmer. He should still be eating well and gaining weight
You may want to try for another child. But it's best to wait one more year. Continue to use family planning methods
ORS is a solution with some sugar & salt. It helps a child with diarrhoea by restoring the water he is losing. ORS can save his life. Buy some & keep at home
Is your child behaving badly? Think about how your family behaves around your child. Children pick up most of their bad habits by copying!
If your child has been bitten or scratched by an animal, wash the wound with clean water. To prevent infection, take him to the clinic
Does your baby sleep on a raised bed? Put cushions on the floor next to the bed. Now he won't get hurt if he rolls off!
Chest pain and a cough that lasts over three weeks are signs of TB. You can protect your child by getting treatment from the clinic
Do not feed your child food from outside stalls. It could contain germs. Instead, take a snack and clean water with you when you go out
If your child has diarrhoea, he needs thick, nutritious food. Thick food, clean water and rest will help him get well again
It's better to praise good behaviour, than to punish bad behaviour. Your child wants to please you
If your child has a cold, a fever and ear pain, it could be an ear infection. Take him to the clinic for medicines
If your child has an ear infection, don?t put oil or any herbal medicine. It will make it worse. Go to a hospital to get the right medicine
If your child has a fever that lasts more than a day, take him to the clinic immediately. A simple fever could cause a seizure
Mosquitoes are attracted to still water. Pour away any unused containers or vases of water in and around your home
Train your child to pass stools in a toilet or let him use a potty. You can dispose of his stools in a toilet. Wash your hands after
Cough and fast or difficult breathing are signs of illness. Take your child to the clinic as soon as your child shows these signs
Encourage your child to exercise regularly even from a young age. Start with daily household chores such as sweeping as soon as possible
Fever in your child is not to be taken lightly. If your child has a fever that lasts more than a day, take him to the clinic immediately!
Fever, headache, chills and vomiting are signs of illness. If your child shows any of these signs, take him to the clinic get him checked
If your child has malaria make sure he takes all the medicines prescribed at the hospital. With the right treatment, malaria can be cured
Keep your child away from animal and human stools and keep areas where he plays as clean as possible. This prevents germs from spreading
Explain to your child why rules are necessary. Tell him that it's not safe to run out into the street without holding a grown-up's hand
If your child's eyes are sticky or pink, it may be an eye infection. Take him to the clinic for treatment. He may be in some pain
If your child has an eye infection, bathe his eyes in cool boiled water to soothe them. Don?t let anyone use your child?s wash cloth
Wash your child's bed linen, towels and clothes with hot water and soap. Clean bedding and clothes helps to prevent infections
If a family member is coughing a lot, ask them to cough into a cloth and wash the cloth every day. This will stop germs from spreading.
Ask your family members not to spit inside the home. Spitting at home can cause germs to spread and can make your child ill
Encourage your children to wash their own hands. They should use soap and clean water. Teach them to do this before meals
Make a bedtime routine for your child. Doing the same thing at bedtime will help him go to sleep. Perhaps sing a lullaby or tell a story
Other people always have an opinion about how to care for your child. But you know what's best for you and your family
Being a mother is a very important job. Take care of your own health. Eat well, rest and get support from family and friends
Keep giving your child a variety of foods - cereals, beans, meat, fish and lots of  vegetables - for the nutrients he needs
Please remember to make your child?s growth your priority. All he needs is a balanced diet
Pale skin and cold and clammy hands and feet are signs your child is losing fluids. Take your child to clinic immediately for ORS and zinc
Take your child to the clinic if he has spotty red bumps that turn into sores in a few hours. Hospital staff will check if it?s chickenpox
Germs can cause nasty infections. You can help prevent infections by always washing your hands with soap before touching your child
Food that has mould on it is harmful and should not be eaten. Check food before you feed your child and throw it away if it is mouldy
Get your partner involved in small tasks like bathing and playing with your child. Fathers can play a big role in caring for children
Make sure your child eats a variety of food every day. Eating well helps to build up your child's defenses against illness
Take your child to the clinic for deworming medicine. Deworming medicine kills any worms your child may have picked up
Make sure your child gets deworming medicine every 6 months. Deworming is safe even if your child has not picked up any worms
Your child's balance is getting much better! He can now hop from one foot to the other.
Ask your family members to help you with your daily chores. Being a mother is hard work
Blisters around your child?s nose and mouth which burst to form scabs may be a skin infection. Take him to the clinic for medicine
Keep the scabs on your child?s skin clean to prevent it from spreading. Gently wash them with water and soap twice a day and pat them dry
Your child can't recognize danger like you can. Cover any containers of water in and around your home so your child doesn?t fall in
A child recovering from dehydration will pass more urine and not feel thirsty all the time. Keep giving extra fluids until he gets well
Is your child refusing to brush his teeth or go to bed? This is common. Keep trying, he will soon imbibe the habit of always brushing his teeth
Teach your child to wash his hands regularly with soap after using the toilet and before eating. Dirty hands can cause infections
Does your child hit? Don't hit him back. Make eye contact and firmly tell him that he hurt you and made you sad
Keep your child away from crowded places. He can easily catch infections when he?s among lots of people whose health you?re not sure of
If your child gets a heat rash, wipe him with a wet cloth and let the air dry his skin. Go to the clinic for cream to soothe the rash
Your child is curious and adventurous. He will want to explore. Watch him, to make sure he doesn't hurt himself
If your child has chickenpox, apply the cream you get from the hospital to soothe his spots. Don?t let him scratch them
A reddish-brown rash that starts behind the ears and spreads to the rest of the body is probably measles. Take your child to the clinic
Do not leave your child unattended around fires. He won?t understand that fire is dangerous, and may try to touch the flames
Your child should be ready to start using adult toilets. Show him how to use the lavatory. Be patient. If he's not ready, try again in a few weeks
Watch your child next to stoves and cooking fires. He could burn himself. If he does get burnt, pour cool water over the burn
Are you trying to get pregnant? Make sure you have a healthy, varied diet. It will help you have a healthy pregnancy
Worldwide a woman dies of cervical cancer every two minutes. See your doctor to learn more about the screening for cervical cancer
Do a pap smear today to know if you stand the risk of having cervical cancer. It is free in most centres and it might just save your life
Do not give your child hot drinks. He could spill them and burn himself. Leave hot drinks to cool before you give them to him
If your child gets burnt, pour cool water over the burn. Do not put anything else on it! If the burn is serious, take him to the hospital
Do not put any traditional ointments or food items on burns, such as butter, oil or herbs. Instead, pour cool, clean water over the burn
Your child is learning to take care of himself. Give him lots of praise whenever he tries something new - even if he doesn't succeed!
If a family member smokes, ask him to smoke outside the house away from your child. Breathing in smoke can cause illnesses like pneumonia
Make sure all food you feed your child is fresh. If the smell or appearance has changed, it may have spoiled. Spoiled food can cause sickness
Store food in a cool, dry place. This will keep the food fresh. If food is left in the sun or damp, it can spoil. Spoiled food can cause sickness
Has your child successfully used a toilet? Clap and praise him when he does this. It will encourage him to continue
Does someone else take care of your child? Show them some of our messages. That way, they won't undo all the good work you've done!
Is your child coughing a lot, and making a whooping sound in between breaths? Take him to the clinic. He may need treatment
Ask caregivers to wash their hands with soap before preparing food and after using the toilet. This will protect your child from illness
If your child has swallowed chemicals, take him to the hospital fast. Take the container with you, so doctors know the ingredients
Trust your instincts. If you think your child is unwell, take him to the clinic. You know him better than anyone else, so trust yourself
If your child feels unwell, get him to the hospital for treatment. It's best to get treatment as early as possible
Your child is old enough to learn about road safety. Teach him to look both directions before crossing a road. He should walk slowly
Your child is 5 years! Congratulations! Think of how much your child has accomplished. This is all down to you. Well done!
